title: All Course Materials + Additional Readings & Resources Organized by Topic
section: Applied studies referenced in EDS 241 - organized by topic!
text:
Applied studies referenced in EDS 241 - organized by topic!

Data science - general topics
Reproducibility

Lowndes et al., 2017 - Our path to better science in less time using open data science tools
Gehlman & Loken, 2013 - The garden of forking paths: Why multiple comparisons can be a problem, even when there is no ‚Äúfishing expedition‚Äù or ‚Äúp-hacking‚Äù

Data viz

Animated Visualizations - ‚ÄòR Psychologist‚Äô - Kristoffer Magnusson
Larsen, Meng, & Kendall 2018 - Causal analysis in control‚Äìimpact ecological studies with observational data



Regression
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
Generalized Linear Models (GLMs)

Carruthers et al., 2008 - Generalized linear models: model selection, diagnostics, and overdispersion



Causal inference - Econometrics
Causal inference research conducted at Bren & UCSB

Sarah Anderson - Monitoring ‚Üí Compliance
Mark Buntaine - Citizen participation ‚Üí Env. Policy
Joan Dudney - Climate change ‚Üí Infectious tree disease
Leah Stokes - Voting ‚Üí Climate policy
Olivier Deschenes - Climate change ‚Üí Agricultural output
Matto Mildenberger - Wildfires ‚Üí Voting
Kyle Meng - Marine Reserves, Inequality, Ground water rights



Experimental Design

Buntaine et al., 2024 - Social competition drives collective action to reduce informal waste burning in Uganda

EDS 241 - Glossary of Econometric and Statistical Terms
J-PAL power calculation tool
EGAP power calculation tool




Difference-in-Difference Design

Moland et al., 2013 - Lobster and cod benefit from small-scale northern marine protected areas: inference from an empirical before‚Äì after control-impact study



Regression Discontinuity Design







Instrumental Variable Design

Today‚Äôs topic here

Week 1 | January 6th, 2025

title: EDS 241
text:
Welcome to EDS 123!


This is the default text size




I can apply a class selector from meds-slides-styles.scss to change the size of this text



Similarly, I can apply a class selector(s) to modify the appearance of a subset of text

Check out this demo presentation for examples of all the cool capabilities of Revealjs

title: EDS 241
text:
You can also apply styles to blocks of content

We can use divs to apply styling to all content within the div gates (:::):
::: {.selector1 .selector2}
Some content
:::

For example:

This text is bolded
This text is italicized

title: EDS 241
text:
Here is some embedded & rendered code


library(palmerpenguins)
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species)) +
  geom_point()

title: EDS 241
text: Alternatively, we can render just the output

title: EDS 241
text:
You can arrange content in columns



Learn more about the MEDS program on the Bren website.

title: Week 9:
text: Extra resources

title: EDS 241 - Environmental Policy Evaluation
text:
Course Description
This course will present state of the art program evaluation techniques necessary to evaluate the impact of environmental policies. The program evaluation methods presented will aim at identifying and measuring the causal effect of policies, regulations, and interventions on environmental outcomes of interest. Students will learn the research designs and methods for estimating causal effects with experimental and non-experimental data. This will prepare the students for interpreting and conducting high-quality empirical research, with applications in cross-sectional data and panel data settings.

title: Assignments
text:
Important: Email group presentation slides to instructor (Adam) before 7am on presentation day! (3/19)




Presentation slides must be emailed to your instructor (Adam) before 7am (3/19)
Acceptable submission formats include google slides or a shared link of the slides in pdf format (i.e., a Google Drive link)
If slides are available in advance please send early!

title: Lab 1.1 KEY
text:
# load packages ----
library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

title: Lab 1.1 KEY
text:
# load packages ----
library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

title: Lab 1.1 KEY
text:
Tidy Data Review
Example untidy / wide data:

# create some untidy temperature data ----
temp_data_wide <- tribble(
  ~date, ~station1, ~station2,  ~station3,
  "2023-10-01", 30.1, 29.8,  31.2,
  "2023-11-01", 28.6, 29.1,  33.4,
  "2023-12-01", 29.9, 28.5,  32.3
)

# print it out ----
print(temp_data_wide)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 4
  date       station1 station2 station3
  <chr>         <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
1 2023-10-01     30.1     29.8     31.2
2 2023-11-01     28.6     29.1     33.4
3 2023-12-01     29.9     28.5     32.3


Using pivot_longer() to ‚Äúlengthen‚Äù / tidy our data:

# convert data from wide > long ----
temp_data_long <- temp_data_wide %>%  
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("station"),
               names_to = "station_id",
               values_to = "temp_c")

# print it out ----
print(temp_data_long)

# A tibble: 9 √ó 3
  date       station_id temp_c
  <chr>      <chr>       <dbl>
1 2023-10-01 station1     30.1
2 2023-10-01 station2     29.8
3 2023-10-01 station3     31.2
4 2023-11-01 station1     28.6
5 2023-11-01 station2     29.1
6 2023-11-01 station3     33.4
7 2023-12-01 station1     29.9
8 2023-12-01 station2     28.5
9 2023-12-01 station3     32.3
